Authors:
Ana Catalina Lara , Diego Mauricio Riaño-Pachon, Martha J.
Vives-Florez
Title:
DIFERENT SIZE OF ACCESSORY GENOME OF CLINICAL AND
ENVIRONMENTAL STRAINS OF Pseudomonas aeruginosa ARE PRODUCT OF ALEATORY
VARIATION
Keywords:
P. AERUGINOSA, core genome, environmental strains,
comparative genomics, clinical strains, genetic determinants,
orthologs.
Abstract:
Background: P. AERUGINOSA is a gram negative, rod-shaped
and common bacterium that can cause infection in animals and plants but
can also degrade complex organic compounds. It is associated to aquatic
or humid environments and has a great metabolic potential. By using
orthologs groups, we aimed to identify the genomic determinants of P.
AERUGINOSA adaptability by deciphering core and accessory genomes for
two groups of origin: the clinical and the environmental group. We added
new data by sequencing four new environmental strains, three isolated
from crude oil-contaminated samples and one from cow manure. Results:
Functional annotation of the newly sequenced genomes and re-annotation
of the database-retrieved genomes revealed that in the accessory genome
of the two groups of origin not all the functional groups were
represented. From the 7005 groups of orthologous genes in P. aeruginosa
strains, 56 are associated with the accessory genome of environmental
strains and 9 of these 56 are phage or mobile elements. In contrast, in
the clinical strains 379 groups of orthologous genes comprise the
accessory genome, 26 of these being related to phage or mobile elements.
P. aeruginosa, P. putida and P. mendocina share 4306 genetic
determinants identified in the core genome, implying that these shared
genetic determinants were present before species diversification.
Blombergs K is a standardized measure of the phylogenetic signal and
only 7 out of 28 genetic functional categories have K>1 or a strong
phylogenetic signal so most genetic functional groups are changing in a
random way along the proposed phylogeny. Notably, genome-wide average
nucleotide identity and alignment fraction showed the distance between
one P. aeruginosa clinical strains (PA7) to the rest of P aeruginosa
strains would large enough to suggest the exclusion of PA7 from the P.
aeruginosa species. Finally, we identified a higher number of
phage-related proteins, toxins and efflux systems in the clinical group
than in the environmental group. Conclusions: The reported core genome
of P. AERUGINOSA, 6359 genetic determinants include quite a large
proportion of genetic determinants shared with other Pseudomonas
species, in our case 4306 (67,71%). The genome landscape of P.
aeruginosa as a species has two groups with different accessory genomes
sizes in terms of number of ortholog haplotypes. Having in mind this
might result from the existing bias in favor of clinical strains
information, the environmental group showed more stability (56 unique
determinants) when compared to the clinical group (379 unique
determinants). These differences are not reflected in the media size
(bps) of the genomes or in the functional groups represented.
